text: Guys did everyone see the Nexus 9 and the set top Nexus thingy from yesterday?
<http://www.google.com/nexus/9/>

attachments.title: Nexus
attachments.text: Designed for work, play, and you

text: I kind of love the 9 I think
And the Nexus Player, but I can't see how its different from CCast
<http://www.google.com/nexus/player/>
Looks good.
But "Introducing Lollipop, our sweetest release yet" may just be too much for me.
I dunno: "front-facing HTC BoomSoundâ„¢"
Hm. The nexus 9 is also insanely expensive.
Nexus player seems quite a bit more robust than the chromecast
no phone necessary
But seems to focus on the gaming?
which is odd
I don't get it either, but everyone wanted the chromecast to work for gaming, which wasn't ever going to work very well
ahhh
Chromecast is for screen sharing only basically - you can beam content from your phone/laptop to it so you can see it on the big screen...  but beyond that it didn't actually "do" anything really.
Player is straight up going after AppleTV and Roku and xbox
so it's a full fledged device.
Makes sense
No pricing yet
I thought it was like 99$
not sure where I saw that
If their Nexus 9/6 prices are any indicator, it will be about 100 bucks more expensive than it should be
or in the case of the 6 specifically, 250 bucks too expensive
sorry, i dont know why the price of the 6 bugs me so much
maybe because the 9 is also pretty expensive but is just an android tablet
at the end of the day
switching topics...
This is a really smart move...  <https://www.facebook.com/about/safetycheck/>

attachments.title: Facebook Safety Check
attachments.text: Connect with friends and loved ones during a disaster.

text: but where's the "not safe" button?
I was totally wondering exactly that!
It's an interesting play from a business perspective -
make people feel better that their family is safe, but don't actually help anyone who needs it...
I'm going to preorder the nexus 9, I like my Transformer a lot, but it's ready to be replaced

I'm in

Remember when Apple used to care
The fix for the above error is:

1. Open your target's Info.plist
2. Select an entry in the plist and then select "Show raw keys & values" from the Editor menu
3. Ensure the key "LSRequiresIPhoneOS" has the value "YES" (add it if necessary)
4. Regenerate your archive and submit
But!
It doesn't fix this:
A file was shared
Solution: use application loader

Am I the only Android dev who struggles hard with animations? I've spent the entire day so far modifying hundreds of lines of XML and Java, reorganizing a complex view hierarchy and repeatedly TDDing, and I have only implemented 0.5 seconds of a complex 5-second animation that the client made (in AE, I assume). So frustrating.
:thumbsdown: No bueno
yep. Same here. Android and Animation have never been pals.
If you ever do animation on iOS it will make you even sadder
because iOS took layer and caching into account
when designing their animation framework
yikes... I know it's important and all, but wow it's so time-consuming... by far the most time-consuming dev task I always save for after I've implemented all the other stuff
animation on Mac isn't much fun either. If you ever want to rotate anything around an arbitrary point (instead of its origin) things get complicated very quickly
maybe over christmas break I'll read this book <http://www.amazon.com/Core-Animation-Mac-iPhone-Programmers/dp/1934356107>
<@U026PT0D7> Isn't that the case with most frameworks? Ran into the same annoyance with CSS and Canvas earlier this week.
In this particular case I think Apple could have provided a convenience method
Core Graphics does have "setAnchorPoint" but that moves the contents of the view to the new anchor point, rather than moving the invisible anchor point through the contents
Good point.
Once UIView animations get ported to desktop, that gets a lot easier
looking into CALayer <@U026PT0D7>
Yeah, there's a lot you can do with a CABasicAnimation on a view's layer
